channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: An American Vision Emerges for Postwar Gaza, but It Faces Obstacles
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state, Antony J. Blinken, said Gaza should be overseen by the Palestinian Authority, which has a tenuous hold on power in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times

item.title: Israel and Hamas Nearly Struck a Deal to Free Up to 50 Hostages
item.description: Indirect talks mediated by Qatar snagged after Israel’s ground invasion of Gaza on Oct. 27. They have resumed, but hopes for a quick release have faded.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Matthew Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: People attend a rally on Monday in Jerusalem supporting families of the captives held by Hamas.

item.title: Israel Raises Alarms by Suggesting ‘Indefinite’ Role in Gaza
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken quickly pushed back, but what exactly comes next is far from clear.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Isabel Kershner
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli tank operating near the border with Gaza in Israel this month.

item.title: Behind Hamas’s Bloody Gambit to Create a ‘Permanent’ State of War
item.description: Hamas leaders say they waged their Oct. 7 attack on Israel because they believed the Palestinian cause was slipping away, and that only violence could revive it.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians surveying the damage caused by Israeli airstrikes in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, last month.

item.title: As Ukraine Seeks Troops, Women Prepare for the Call
item.description: With so much in the war against Russia hinging on refilling the ranks of soldiers, efforts are underway to draw more Ukrainian women into the army.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women participating in a course in firearms and urban combat in a forest near Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, last month.

item.title: France Suspects Foreign Influence in Star of David Graffiti
item.description: After more than 200 blue stars were stenciled on buildings in and around Paris, prosecutors say they are investigating whether a foreign intermediary paid a couple to spray paint them.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: More than 60 blue stars were found in the 14th arrondissement of Paris on the morning of Oct. 31, while others have appeared in two suburbs of the capital.

item.title: Germans Recoil at Push to Rename ‘Anne Frank’ Day Care
item.description: The proposed change, reportedly at the behest of parents and employees who found her story difficult to explain to children, comes amid acute concern about rising antisemitism in Germany.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.media:description: Anne Frank, a young Jewish girl who became one of the most well-known victims of the Holocaust, pictured in 1941. She died at the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp toward the end of World War II.

item.title: Ukraine Gets an Encouraging Sign in Its Bid to Join the E.U.
item.description: The European Union’s executive arm recommended beginning membership talks with Ukraine on condition of some further changes in Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, the head of the European Commission, said on Wednesday that Ukrainians were “deeply reforming their country” even as they fought to defend it.

item.title: Orban’s Dream of an Illiberal Pan-European Alliance Is Fading
item.description: The Hungarian leader’s efforts have been undermined by setbacks for some of his political allies across Europe and deep divisions over the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary at the European Union leaders’ summit in Brussels last month. Mr. Orban’s hopes of leading a pan-European movement are fading.

item.title: A New Answer for Migrants in Central America: Bus Them North
item.description: Costa Rica and Panama are busing people through their countries to ease the concentration of people along their borders, which Biden officials fear will encourage more people to travel to the U.S. border.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, David Bolaños and Daniele Volpe
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants, mostly Venezuelans, waiting to get access to the bus that will take them to the border with Nicaragua last month in Paso Canoa, Costa Rica.

item.title: Arab States Intensify Pleas for Gaza Cease-fire as Public Anger Mounts
item.description: Citing deepening fears for regional stability, Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries are beseeching the U.S. to push Israel to end its military campaign in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: A rally in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza Strip in Amman, Jordan, on Oct. 27.

item.title: António Costa, Portugal’s Prime Minister, Resigns Unexpectedly
item.description: He quit shortly after prosecutors announced raids on government buildings as part of an investigation into corruption.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Prime Minister António Costa of Portugal in September. He resigned on Tuesday.

item.title: Italian Officials Question Meloni’s Deal to Divert Migrants to Albania
item.description: The prime minister heralded a deal with Italy’s Adriatic neighbor as a model for Europe. Politicians question if it is legal, ethical or practical.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Gaia Pianigiani
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Prime Minister Edi Rama of Albania and Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy during a news conference in Rome where they signed an agreement on migrations on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Strikes Iran-Linked Facility in Syria in Round of Retaliation
item.description: Drone and rocket attacks on U.S. forces have continued in recent weeks, prompting a second round of retaliatory airstrikes in eastern Syria.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Air Force F-15E jets carried out the strikes.

item.title: Tens of Thousands Evacuate Northern Gaza as Israel’s Invasion Advances
item.description: The United Nations estimated that 15,000 civilians walked out of northern Gaza on Tuesday, three times as many as the day before, while Israeli troops battled Hamas in Gaza City.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gazans displaced from the North walking along Salah al-Din Road on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Accuses Russia of Deadly Strike on Civilian Ship in Black Sea
item.description: The episode, which killed one and injured four others, comes amid a recent uptick in military activity and attacks in the Black Sea, a hot spot in the war between Russia and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A photo released by the Ukrainian authorities showed a damaged civilian ship flying the Liberian flag that Ukraine said had been hit by a Russian missile in the Black Sea region of Odesa.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: What’s Next in the Israel-Hamas War
item.description: Plus, a cook’s tour of the Tokyo food scene.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel’s bombardment of Gaza has left over 10,000 Gazans dead, according to the Gazan health ministry.

item.title: A Gaza ‘Cease-Fire’ or a ‘Pause’? Even World Leaders Are Confused.
item.description: Experts say neither term is defined under international law.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed area after an Israeli airstrike on Khan Younis, in southern Gaza.

item.title: As Israel Pushes Deeper Into Northern Gaza, Thousands Trek South
item.description: The United Nations estimates that 15,000 people used the only route out of the northern part of the enclave on Tuesday, three times the number that passed the day before.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of Gazans fled the north part of the strip on Wednesday, as the Israeli incursion into Gaza City intensified this week. Displaced residents used carriages pulled by beasts of burden, bicycles, cars or even walked in search of refuge from the Israeli attack.

item.title: Reading List: Scams and Scammers
item.description: Sam Bankman-Fried’s conviction reminds us of the real talent behind the schemes — knowing what people yearn for.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Sam Bankman-Fried, who founded the FTX cryptocurrency exchange, leaving court in July.

item.title: Sunak Clashes With Police Chief Over Planned Pro-Palestinian March
item.description: A demonstration in London that will coincide with remembrance events has divided the prime minister and the country’s most senior police officer.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: A Pro-Palestinian protest in London last Saturday. Demonstrators called for a cease-fire in the Hamas-Israel conflict.

item.title: 2023 Virtually Certain to Be the Hottest Year on Record, Scientists Say
item.description: Analyzing data from October, European climate scientists found another record-breaking month for temperatures around the world.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Employees of the City Council in São Paulo, Brazil, distributed bottled water during a heat wave in September.

item.title: Senate Democrats Challenge Biden on Israel, Seeking Assurances About Aid
item.description: A majority of the Democratic caucus signed a letter asking President Biden to ensure that Israel has a viable plan for defeating Hamas and will use U.S. military assistance in keeping with international law.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senate Democrats asked for details on how the Biden administration would ensure that Israel was properly mitigating civilian casualties in Gaza.

item.title: Lucky Find at Auction Identifies Man on Cover of ‘Led Zeppelin IV’
item.description: It’s not a painting. It’s a picture of a Victorian artisan taken in the English countryside in 1892.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: As Pandas Leave National Zoo, Is Panda Diplomacy Over?
item.description: The giant pandas have left Washington. Some fans find it unbearable.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Erin Schaff
item.media:description: The Smithsonian’s National Zoo in the heart of Washington has panda posters, panda mugs, panda pajamas, panda puzzles and even panda ice cream.

item.title: Wage Hike Fails to Appease Protesting Garment Workers in Bangladesh
item.description: Unions in Bangladesh say a proposed wage increase falls short after a weekend of violent protests.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers at a garment factory on the outskirts of Dhaka, Bangladesh, in July.

item.title: Drought in Syria, Iran and Iraq Made ‘Extreme’ by Global Warming, Attribution Study Says
item.description: Syria, Iraq and Iran were parched by high temperatures that would have been “virtually impossible” without the effects of global warming, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mashoofs, a type of boat used by residents of Mesopotamia’s marshes, parked at the edge of a shrinking waterway in Chibayish, Iraq, in 2022.

item.title: Éric Dupond-Moretti, France’s Justice Minister, Goes on Trial
item.description: The case is the first time a sitting government minister has gone before a court, and it is part of the system he continues to oversee.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Justice Minister Éric Dupond-Moretti at the Élysée Palace in July. Mr. Dupond-Moretti faces a 10-day trial.

item.title: Underwater Volcano Forms New Island in Japan
item.description: An ongoing eruption from the volcano has created a small land mass less than a mile off Iwo Jima island. It’s a great case study of how volcanoes work.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Photos showing the eruption from an underwater volcano in Japan last weekend.

item.title: How One Small Statistic Became a Story That Spanned a Continent
item.description: Our chief Africa reporter was wary of journalism that made broad predictions about the continent, but a statistic made clear that staggering change was approaching.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Hannah Reyes Morales for The New York Times
item.media:description: With a median age of 19, Africa is the continent with the world’s youngest population. Senegal’s youth can be felt at Yoff Beach in Dakar, the capital.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Calls for a cease-fire in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A rally in Amman, Jordan, to show support for Palestinians in Gaza.

item.title: Fossil Fuel Use Increasing, Not Decreasing, as Key Target Looms
item.description: The world remains on track to produce far more oil, gas and coal than would be consistent with relatively safe levels of heating, a new report found.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A gas processing plant in Seminole, Texas. Emissions from burning coal, oil and gas are the main drivers of global warming,

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg Taps the Strengths of WhatsApp
item.description: The messaging app, which Meta bought nearly a decade ago, was an asset that Mr. Zuckerberg largely left alone for a while. No longer.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, has positioned WhatsApp as a “next chapter” for the social networking company.

item.title: Peace Corps, Criticized for Medical Care, Settles Wrongful-Death Suit for $750,000
item.description: Bernice Heiderman, a 24-year-old Peace Corps volunteer, died of undiagnosed malaria in the African island nation of Comoros in 2018. Her family sued.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Joshua Lott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Before she died, Bernice Heiderman, the daughter of Julie and Bill Heiderman, complained to her family that her Peace Corps doctor had been dismissive of her medical complaints.

item.title: Netanyahu Says Israel Will Control Gaza Security After War
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel would be at risk of another major attack if it did not remain engaged in the Palestinian enclave.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Karen Zraick, Victoria Kim and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said his country was preparing to play at least some role in controlling Gaza after the fighting ends.

item.title: Tesla Faces Blockade in All Swedish Ports, Union Says
item.description: Swedish unions are joining in blockades and targeted strikes against the U.S. automaker over its refusal to sign a collective bargaining agreement with its mechanics.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Christina Anderson
item.media:description: Tesla’s service center in Segeltorp, Sweden. Workshop workers have gone on strike demanding that the company sign a collective agreement.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Israel Plans a Long-Term Role in Gaza
item.description: Plus, China shifts the focus of its lending.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians investigated following Israeli airstrikein Khan Younis, in the Southern Gaza Strip, on Tuesday.

item.title: As War Closes In, Many Remain in Northern Gaza
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of people are still in the region, despite Israel’s bombing, ground invasion and evacuation directive. Many say the trip to the south is too dangerous.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick, Vivian Yee and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The Shati refugee camp in Gaza City was one of the neighborhoods hit by Israeli airstrikes on Monday. Hundreds of thousands of people have remained in northern Gaza despite warnings to move south.

item.title: ‘Something Was Wrong’: Ukrainians Lament Deaths at Medal Ceremony
item.description: A gathering in plain sight of so many soldiers was reckless, critics said, and evoked a rigid adherence to Soviet-era military tradition.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova

item.title: Orcas Keep Sinking Boats Off Iberia, Unnerving Sailors
item.description: Orcas caused enough damage to sink a yacht in the Strait of Gibraltar last week. A small pod has been slamming boats in recent years, worrying skippers charting routes closer to shore.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: An orca seen near the boats of Moroccan fishermen in the Strait of Gibraltar in 2015.

item.title: Israeli Shekel Regains Value Lost Against Dollar After Attacks
item.description: The currency is now back to about where it was before the attacks on Oct. 7, after falling to an eight-year low.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman

item.title: Ukraine Investigates Birthday Grenade Blast That Killed Military Aide
item.description: Maj. Gennadiy Chastyakov, an aide to Ukraine’s top commander, died when a grenade given to him as a gift blew up.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in the Donetsk region last month. The grenade blast on Monday came at a delicate moment for the Ukrainian Army, whose troops are currently bogged down in inconclusive fighting with Russian forces.

item.title: Thailand Hopes Its Hostages in Gaza Will Be the Next to Be Released
item.description: Thai officials have seen photos of the hostages who were abducted on Oct. 7 in southern Israel.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Ryn Jirenuwat and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pornchai Angkaew and Watsana Yojampa, parents of one of the presumed Thai hostages. Ms. Watsana said on Tuesday that they had not had any communication with Thai or Israeli government officials about their son’s status.

item.title: Viewed Warily by Democrats, a Netanyahu Ally Is a Key Conduit to U.S.
item.description: Ron Dermer sits in Israel’s five-member war cabinet and is a crucial liaison to the Biden administration, including U.S. officials he clashed with when he was ambassador to Washington.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Ron Dermer, former Israeli Ambassador to the United States, and current member of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s war cabinet, in the Knesset last year.

item.title: Under Scrutiny Over Gaza, Israel Points to Civilian Toll of U.S. Wars
item.description: Israeli officials say it is impossible to defeat Hamas without killing innocents, a lesson they argue Americans and their allies should understand.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Praying over the bodies of children in Gaza on Sunday. More than 10,000 people have been killed in Gaza over the past month, 40 percent of them children, according to the health ministry there.

item.title: Thousands of Gazans fled south during a window given by Israel, the U.N. says.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Residents evacuating Gaza City on foot on Monday.

item.title: Charles Delivers A ‘King’s Speech’ He Probably Disdained
item.description: In keeping with tradition, he outlined the priorities of the prime minister at the opening of Parliament — including, this year, more fossil fuel extraction.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: King Charles III showed the poker face expected of a British monarch as he set out the government’s legislative program.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The death toll in Gaza climbs.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Civil defense crews on Monday removing a child from the remains of a house in Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Brazil Cracks Down on Surprising New Threat: Neo-Nazis
item.description: The Brazilian government has raided neo-Nazi groups across 10 states this year, part of a push by the new Lula administration to prosecute far-right extremists.
item.dc:creator: Julia Vargas Jones
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police raid aimed at dismantling neo-Nazi groups in Nova Petrópolis, Brazil, last summer.

item.title: Israel Says It Has Split Gaza Strip in Two in Drive to Isolate Hamas’s Leadership
item.description: Israel’s military surrounded Gaza City as the enclave plunged into another communications blackout, sowing panic among relatives fearful of the fate of loved ones who remain there.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson, Adam Entous and Andrés R. Martínez
item.media:description: Smoke rising in Gaza City on Monday after Israeli strikes.

item.title: Gaza Death Toll Has Hit 10,000, Its Health Ministry Says
item.description: The figures could not be independently verified, but a Pentagon spokesman acknowledged on Monday that “we know the numbers are in the thousands.”
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Civil defense crews on Monday removing a child from the remains of a house in Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Biden Confronts Limits of U.S. Leverage in Israel and Ukraine Wars
item.description: President Biden’s influence over Israel and Ukraine seems far more constrained than expected, given his central role as the supplier of arms and intelligence.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s legacy is bound to be shaped by the two wars, even if the most important decisions in them are made in Israel and Ukraine.

item.title: Statue of Liberty Is the Setting for an Israel-Hamas War Protest
item.description: Protests over the war have been organized almost daily across the United States.
item.dc:creator: Camille Baker
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Activists with Jewish Voice for Peace rallied in front of the Statue of Liberty on Monday to call for a cease-fire in Gaza.

item.title: Democrats in Congress Weigh Calls for Cease-Fire Amid Pressure From the Left
item.description: They have grown more vocal about urging measures to mitigate civilian casualties in Gaza, but supporters of a cease-fire are few and far between.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators rallied in Washington on Saturday.

item.title: Four Men Charged in the Case of the Missing Golden Toilet
item.description: The fully functioning 18-karat gold toilet, an artwork estimated to be worth $5.9 million, was stolen in 2019 from an exhibition at a stately British home.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Tom Lindboe, via Blenheim Art Foundation
item.media:description: The 18-karat gold toilet, an artwork by the Italian conceptual artist Maurizio Cattelan, at Blenheim Palace in Oxfordshire, England, before it disappeared.

item.title: Biden Administration, After Setbacks, Talks Up Renewable Power Gains
item.description: The administration said 15 clean energy projects were making solid progress and that it was on track to meet its goals for 2025.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: A Ford F-150 Lightning electric truck on the assembly line in a plant in Dearborn, Mich.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Israel Cuts the Gaza Strip in Two
item.description: Plus, Trump testifies at his civil fraud trial.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians inspected the damage to a house, which was destroyed by Israeli air strikes, in Khan Yunis in the southern Gaza Strip., on Monday.

item.title: Imprisoned Nobel Winner and Iranian Rights Activist Begins a Hunger Strike
item.description: Narges Mohammadi is protesting the prison’s denial of hospital treatment for her heart condition, her family said.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Cassandra Vinograd
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Nobel laureate Narges Mohammadi is serving a 10-year sentence in Iran’s Evin prison. “We are extremely worried,” her husband, Taghi Rahmani, said. “Her life is in danger.”
